title: Financial Times Weekend magazine serif typeface.
content:
I snapped this picture while on the tube today of a beautiful serif typeface used on the cover of the Financial Times Weekend magazine. Any ideas what it could be?

Thanks in advance.

Chris.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451im_/http:/typophile.com/files/IMG_2605_5885.jpg)
author: chrisbolton

comments.content:
Some version of Didot compressed? Note the extreme thick & thin contrast and hairline squared serifs. But I don't recognize this version offhand. Perhaps proprietary.

Fairly close is Typofonderie's AmbroiseStdFirminLight:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AmbroiseStdFirminLight_5040.jpg)

Some Didots, like this Ambroise and one from Canada Type have ball terminals similar to your image, while other Didots have a gradual flow into the hairline stroke.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DidotDisplayDemiCT_5659.jpg)

Don

I should have recalled this one.  
Somebody with more time than prudence could do a digital swash version to match the creation by Photo Display, which seems to date from the 1970s. Nebillo's creation with a disco beat :)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TorinoSwashBasedOnNebillo_6515.jpg)
  
Don

Jason Walcott digitized the swashes though.  
 [http://marketplace.veer.com/font/Torino-Pro-JBT0001068?stermids=100211489](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451/http:/marketplace.veer.com/font/Torino-Pro-JBT0001068?stermids=100211489 "http://marketplace.veer.com/font/Torino-Pro-JBT0001068?stermids=100211489")  
 [http://www.jawarts.com/Torino.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803062451/http:/www.jawarts.com/Torino.html "http://www.jawarts.com/Torino.html")
Perfect, thanks for the hard work guys. I really appreciate it.

Impressive!  
Must have been a real challenge to create a workable system for character spacing & kerning.  
Hope he gets some sales.  
Don
